top_comment.text:
Just spent 6 weeks in Singapore, with a significant amount of time speaking 
to people about how Singapore is in a great position to achieve a closed 
loop economy for many of its resources.

It is a city that has invested greatly in "sustainability" over the last 20 
years, but has struggled (failed) on the food front. Tackling food would be 
huge for Singapore opportunity for this nation.

Something this video takes a look at.﻿
top_comment.author: Richard Brubaker

top_comment.author: David Jarvis

comments.text:
Vertical Farming and growing in urban settings is a good way of producing 
certain crops but rice would require a lot of water for realtively low 
yield, traditional farms produce all the food we eat right now, and are not 
at all going to be replaced by this, theres no magic bullet to having 2 
more billion people on earth. This is an interesting technology and should 
be done where it can be, it will be important to continue to have farms and 
maximize their growth. They say it takes about 1-2 acres per person(1-2 
football fields) to grow the food you eat every year, in other places 
people subsist off of less; growing lettuce in towers is a great step in a 
recycling direction and utilizing space in urban environments, but I think 
urban environments will focus on mineral and vitamin plants like veggies 
and maybe eggs or small animals for recycling reasons but grains and larger 
animals will never have a place in the city.

that works well and achieves at least a small part of the vertical farm as

knowledge, this will probably be a well known and well managed method.

comments.text:
It's a great thing this vertical farming at home, and possibly a solution 
for many problems. But there's one tiny thing: Many people on this Earth 
wouldn't be able to take care of a cat and vertical farming seems to me a

care of it, but no savior for the rest of humanity. But then, seven or even 
nine billion people are way too many anyway.

comments.text:
DIANNA SKARE
Many cultures ,farther back then written history, did this and fed hundreds 
IF NOT THOUSANDS (South America , North American, Middle East , etc.... , 
why would it be any different for our time ? It sure is healthier to grow 
our own Fresh Produce then use Anything that is mass-produced with all the 
chemicals !!! Green Buildings use the waste from the gardens for mulch and 
fresh fish waste(from buildings aquariums) for fertilizer , throw in a few 
earthworms to reproduce and do their thing and these gardens would have 
Plenty of nitrogen and rich nutrients to feed any type of plant...not to 
mention companion planting and rotations of plants . Along with full water 
and power collecting is an Awesome idea and Needed badly NOW !!!
comments.author: Gene Skare

comments.text:
+Tuareg Akavir Look you have a point, but not every nation is as big as 
China. Take Australia for instance, it has alot of land. But most of it is 
arid. Granted Australia has made great strides in creating strains of wheat 
for instance that can grow in extreme conditions, it still doesn't negate 
the fact Australia is arid by in large.

Then you see places like Singapore who import all their food from Malaysia, 
Indonesia and even Australia. Its because they lack the space. And yes its 
a capitalist system so there is no socialist or communist sweeping arm 
giving food for free in nations that don't have the land for it. 

China as you say has alot of land in rural areas? Why then did a large 
Chinese firm buy land from Western Australia to plant their crops in? It 
hardly seems rational. Australia is expensive and surely has more overhead 
than China would want. The thing is China has been doing agriculture for 
thousands of years. It was the breadbasket of Asia for most of recorded 
history. Now if China is running out of good farming land, and swallowing 
it up by urbanisation and doing projects like the Sky City one that will 
house huge greenhouses within its vast internal areas.

How then can we believe China has an abundance of agricultural land to feed 
its 1.3 billion people. It doesn't throw money to such projects because it 
has money to burn. Its just logistically impossible to feed 1.3 billion 
chinese, let alone 7 billion humans on 9.7 million square kilometeres of 
land of which only 15% is arable and of which is diminishing with an ever 
increasing urban sprawl.
comments.author: Marco Polo

comments.text:
+marcopolo3001 i understand you but what you say is not true, its just 
propaganda you ate sadly. just take google maps, turn on satellite mode and 
check china at least 60-70% of china is completely unused and at least half 
of those unused lands are perfect places to grow crops... not even villages 
or roads. they would have a lot of place and space and a lot of poor people 
who could live from the agriculture but its cheaper to produce crap for $2 
in the edge of the city instead of paying the farmers, transports etc... 
the problem in our world is not that we dont have enough food, we could 
feed 3 times the current earth population easily, the problem is that they 
are creating cheaper and cheaper solutions and a lot of ppl fell out of the 
chance to have a decently paid decent job. they are hungry and not because 
we cant produce enough food for them but because they have nothing to pay 
for it.
comments.author: Tuareg Akavir

comments.text:
+Tuareg Akavir Yes we probably do produce more than enough food. God only 
knows how much of it ends up in the supermarket trash cans, just to prop up 
prices. But this is what I am referring to, there will always be waste in a 
capitalist world. Just the other day I was surprised to find that my local 
supermarket throws roasted chickens if not sold within 4 hours. Thats 
right! 4hours, to maintain quality control. This is ridiculous. But so it 
is.

I am all for naturally grown stuff, in fact it would be good if somehow we 
could grow natural stuff vertically the same way some seasteading websites 
propose artificial islands grow their own food on imported soils. But the 
reality is that we won't have enough land to feed the 10-15 billion or so 
by the second half of this century. Alot of the agricultural land is 
disappearing under new urban developments or used for biofuels or something 
else like cotton that doesn't feed anyone.
comments.author: Marco Polo

comments.text:
small naturally grown tomatoes? man. small tomatoes came with the 
massproduction (yes, those are created in genetic labs just like those 
small creepy crops will in those vertical gardens). back on my grandpas 
cornfield only huge, tasty beef tomatoes were seen, some bigger than my 2 
fists together. that was actually veg. and no, its not about survival, its 
about a company what will sell its cheap shit product for the city to get 
rich while the countryside will become even more poor as nobody will buy 
what they can grow in real gardens under the sun. we already produce far 
more than enough food.
comments.author: Tuareg Akavir

comments.text:
+Tuareg Akavir Do you have a problem with feeding people? Its about keeping 
mouths fed, not if something tastes the way it did back in your grandpa's 
cornfield. Sure I understand the need for nutrient rich soil over 
hydroponics. But this is about survival. 

What you might not understand is that hydroponically grown produce yields 
more production and is less exposed to pests. For instance hydroponically 
grown marijuana is not only bigger but has more purity and is more 
expensive on the market because of this. But you can prefer eating your 
small and naturally grown tomatoes anyday, but please don't get in the way 
of some poor soul who wants to actually have something on the dinner table 
vs nothing at all.
comments.author: Marco Polo

top_comment.text:
*Vertical Farming - Singapore*
*[...]In Singapore, the challenge of feeding a growing population is 
pushing the concept of urban farming to new heights. A super-efficient 
vertical farming system is producing greens for 5 million residents*
*"Can we supply enough food for everyone on the planet?" is a question 
plaguing leaders around the world. In Singapore SkyGreen offers one example 
of how this might be possible, "not just technically, but economically". By 
increasing their food security while reducing the impact of food production 
on global climate change, SkyGreen is 10 times more productive per square 
foot than conventional farming.[...]*

#technology #verticalfarming #thevenusproject #resourcebasedeconomy  ﻿
top_comment.author: Cristian Lorenzutti

comments.text:
Right, yes. It'll definitely be an improvement over the existing methods 
where the rain washes half of the fertilizers into the ocean because 
they'll be in a good position to collect and re-use the "run-off". You will 
still lose a bunch of it when the plants leave the farm, but I've seen 
sewage reclamation systems that can keep most of the phosphorus from being 
lost in that manner. Maybe this might save us after all.

comments.text:
Dung is natural, it consists of mineral salts and elements that make the 
soil live. It comes from nature and goes back to nature.
Artificial fertilizers do not do even 1% as good as natural ones.
Food grown on natural ones is tastier, healthier, have more 'substance' 
(strawberries grown on artificial fertilizers are often empty inside, while 
those grown on dung are not).

Artificial fertilizer food tastes worse and is in many aspects worse than 
natural one.

captions.text:
Singapore has one of the highest population
densities on the planet. More than five million

people crowd into this small wealthy island
city. Land here comes at a premium, forcing
people to expand up rather than out.

And it's not just office towers and apartment
complexes that are reaching skyward.

Singapore now has one of the world's first
commercial vertical farms. It's called SkyGreens.
This is the framework. The greenhouse

50 year old entrepreneur, Jack Ng, an engineer
by training, is the farm's owner and designer.

Translucent structures, nearly four stories
tall line the property. On the inside automated

towers of vegetables rotate like Ferris wheels
in slow motion between a nutrient-infused

bath below and the sun above. Ng says each
tower is powered by a gravity-fed water wheel.
It's an ancient technology with a modern twist.

at the top. Ng says one of the biggest benefits
of this closed loop, hydraulic system is how
little energy it consumes.

electricity we use in Singapore it's three
dollars per month [steve couldn't understand]

That's three dollars a month to run this entire
tower... or about the same amount of electricity
used in single 60-watt lightbulb.
You can try the lettuce. OK it's fresh.

Eating local, freshly picked greens is a luxury
in Singapore. With just 250 acres of farmland

left, the city grows only seven percent of
the produce it consumes. That may be an extreme

case, but it represents a looming problem
facing cities all over the world, says Columbia
University ecologist, Dickson Despommier.

We're going to reach a tipping point really
soon where traditional ag can no longer provide
enough food for the people living on the planet.

Despommier says producing enough food for
the three and a half billion people living

in cities today requires an amount of land
twice the size of South America.

Now that would be ok if we could stabilize
our population at 7 billion. But that's not
going to happen.

Despommier believes that 80 percent of the
world's population will be living in cities

by 2050... making today's challenges seem
trivial by comparison.

So the question arises, can we supply enough
food for everybody on the planet including

a growing urban population. And I think we
can. And I think we can do it by empowering
people in the cities to grow food right there.

SkyGreens' vertical farm offers one example
of how that may be possible, not just technically

but also economically. The system is ten times
more productive per square foot than conventional

farming. It also takes a lot less water, labor
and chemical inputs.

Doctor Lee Sing Kong directs Singapore's National
Institute of Education.

I think eventually urban factories for vegetable
production would take place in place of electronic
factories in Singapore.

But Lee says visit any Singapore restaurant
and you can see just how far the country is
from being self-sufficient.

If you look at the plate of food on the table,
say vegetables, it could come from China,

it could come from the neighboring countries
of Indonesia or Malaysia or it could come

in terms of salad greens, as far off as the
US and the European countries like Holland
or Australia....

Maintaining that supply of food from so many
foreign sources is a monumental task. Every

night hundreds of trucks enter Singapore from
Malaysia and beyond, unloading their cargo

of fruit and vegetables at this central wholesale
market. From here the food is loaded onto

smaller trucks and delivered throughout the
city before sunrise.

More than 90 percent of the food in Singapore's
grocery stores like this one comes from foreign

countries. That makes local, urban produce
like SkyGreens a premium novelty for customers.

But to some it's much more than that. It's
an insurance policy.

Supermarkets buy food from dozens of other
countries as a defense against climate-related

disruptions in the global food chain. But
the National Institute of Education's Lee

Sing Kong, says that even that may not be
enough to guarantee a steady food supply in
the future.

We do anticipate that the need for our own
production to a certain level of self-sufficiency.

I think the government has set a target -- initial
target of 10% to 20% of our need and if we

can achieve that I think there will be a great
feat that we have attained.

Singapore recently invested 20 million dollars
in a fund to boost domestic food production

through new farming technologies like SkyGreens.
But Lee says incentives alone aren't ENOUGH

First, he says, high rise farming needs to
be cost competitive.

Whatever we produce in Singapore must compete
with the prices of vegetables coming in Singapore.

// So that's why the government in Singapore
is now encouraging// models of urban farming

that can really not just increase productivity
but also lowering cost of production

Skygreens owner Jack Ng says he's confident
he can compete. Three years into his experiment,

he says his operating costs are only a quarter
of what it would cost to run a conventional
farm.

And since he's local, his transportation costs
are also minimal, making his fresh lettuce

and chinese cabbage price-competitive with
mass-produced, cheap imports.

But most importantly, Ng says they taste better.
He says the "same day" freshness of his greens
is a real selling point.

So far my customer keep on asking us, can
you produce more, can you supply more?

Ng has raised 28 million dollars in public
and private money to more than quadruple his
capacity over the next year and a half.

And in fast rising Singapore, that seems like
a smart investment.

title: The Singapore Vertical-Farms that herald an Agricultural Revolution
